An Introduction to the Archaeology of the Desktop Environment :19 Jan 2015

Smooth movement over Non-Place Rightly credited for the rise of personal computing and a paradigm for interaction that has become the ancestor to a wide range of different computer interfaces, the Desktop Environment (DE) has for decades provided non-technicians with a way to interact with computers, thereby creating a huge market that has been capitalised very successfully. The DE established a Graphical User Interface in order to alleviate the previous requirement of knowing lots of text-based coding languages in order to perform computations, introducing iconography to the interface and opening up opportunities to thereby use computers in new ways. Once...
